body:
Return code 1 is widely used as a generic error indicator on Unix and Windows.
So what's wrong with it?

Ah you probably mean this piece from docs:
https://rclone.org/docs/#list-of-exit-codes

```
0 - success
1 - Syntax or usage error
2 - Error not otherwise categorised
3 - Directory not found
4 - File not found
5 - Temporary error (one that more retries might fix) (Retry errors)
6 - Less serious errors (like 461 errors from dropbox) (NoRetry errors)
7 - Fatal error (one that more retries won't fix, like account suspended) (Fatal errors)
8 - Transfer exceeded - limit set by --max-transfer reached
9 - Operation successful, but no files transferred
```

@ncw 
Feels like this exit code nomenclature had been written years ago and not strictly followed anymore.
At least codes 3 and 4 must have been mixed up recently due error code updates.

Is there a unit test(s) enforcing it?

The exit codes are produced here:

https://github.com/rclone/rclone/blob/25366268fe921608ee68c6dc33b744b80d860abe/cmd/cmd.go#L469-L501

And I guess the issue (if any) is that the message produced here is covered:

https://github.com/rclone/rclone/blob/25366268fe921608ee68c6dc33b744b80d860abe/backend/local/local.go#L999-L1004

> And I guess the issue (if any) is that the message produced here is covered:

Maybe that case statement needs an `fserrors.IsNoLowLevelRetry` test too?

issue.title: Set proper exit code for errors that are not low-level retried (e.g. size/timestamp changing)

repository.name: rclone
repository.description: "rsync for cloud storage" - Google Drive, S3, Dropbox, Backblaze B2, One Drive, Swift, Hubic, Wasabi, Google Cloud Storage, Azure Blob, Azure Files, Yandex Files

issue.body:
#### What is the purpose of this change?

Setting the following exit code when error is NoLowLevelRetryError, same as for NoRetryError:

> 6 - Less serious errors (like 461 errors from dropbox) (NoRetry errors)

Only case where this error is returned, is currently in local backend, when size or timestamp are changing during sync.

#### Was the change discussed in an issue or in the forum before?

Fixes #5785

#### Checklist

- [X] I have read the [contribution guidelines](https://github.com/rclone/rclone/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md#submitting-a-new-feature-or-bug-fix).
- [ ] I have added tests for all changes in this PR if appropriate.
- [ ] I have added documentation for the changes if appropriate.
- [X] All commit messages are in [house style](https://github.com/rclone/rclone/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md#commit-messages).
- [X] I'm done, this Pull Request is ready for review :-)

body:
> Maybe that case statement needs an `fserrors.IsNoLowLevelRetry` test too?

Makes sense. Could only see it used from local backend, when size or timestamp are changing during sync.

Added PR where I suggest setting the following exit code for NoLowLevelRetryError, same as for NoRetryError:

> 6 - Less serious errors (like 461 errors from dropbox) (NoRetry errors)
Is there a PR for this item or more to do? Was searching for a PR and I couldn't find anything to link.
Yep! Thanks as I was searching and apparently not awake enough to put in the right search. I'd say safe to close this out and once that PR gets committed, it solves this item since it's linked now.

I thought it was referenced already, above:

> albertony linked a pull request that will close this issue on 6 Nov

> I'd say safe to close this out and once that PR gets committed, it solves this item since it's linked now.

Yes, that PR will solve it - either as is or it will be updated as necessary to do so. If you want to close this issue before rather than after the PR is merged, is indifferent to me. üëç

Ha, you are double correct. I swear I didn't see it before, but I can see it two places now :) One day when you get older, your eyes will trick you too.

Just trying to clean some things up before the new year so I'll just close it out as @JRDavisUF can follow the PR for tracking purposes as it'll be solved once that is merged.
